21.description:
Plain-text credentials and data; brute-force and directory-traversal exploits let adversaries exfil PLC
programs or drop rogue firmware.

22.description:
Safe when hardened, but weak keys, SSHv1 fall-back, or unmanaged key sprawl enable covert tunnelling,
lateral movement, and persistent access.

23.description: Zero confidentiality or integrity. Sniffing yields clear-text passwords, allowing live writes to controller CLIs.

25.description:
Phishing, relay abuse, and data-exfil tunnels via encoded attachments or header fields. OT alarms sent
by PLCs reveal topology and operator emails.

53.description:
Critical but unencrypted. DNS-tunnel malware (iodine, dnscat2) slips payloads in TXT/resource records.
Cache-poisoning can reroute HMI update URLs to attacker infrastructure.

67-68.description:
Rogue DHCP servers can push malicious default gateways or DNS servers, steering Layer-3 traffic through
attacker-controlled relays.

69.description:
Firmware images move in clear-text and without authentication. Attackers overwrite device boot-code or
pull configs for offline recon.

80.description:
Historian dashboards or IIoT APIs exposed over clear-text leak session cookies and allow JavaScript
injection that tampers with process values.

88.description:
Ticket Granting Tickets (TGTs) are gold to attackers. Pass-the-Ticket and Kerberoasting pivot attacks
compromise engineering-domain admin accounts.

110.description:
Old maintenance accounts still pull backups via POP3. Clear-text credentials harvested here often unlock
VPN or jump-host access.

111.description: Enumerates NFS/lockd services; widely exploited for recon or UDP reflection DDoS.

123.description:
Open NTP daemons aid DDoS and encode covert data in extension fields. Time skew disrupts alarm correlation
and event forensics.

135.description: Core to OPC Classic. EternalBlue-style exploits jump zones, inject shellcode, and create service backdoors.

137.description: NBNS spoofing yields hostname hijack and credential capture with ease.

138.description: Connection-less broadcasts leak asset inventory; datagram spoofing can DoS antiquated HMI nodes.

139.description: Grants unauthenticated share enumeration; attackers copy recipe files or drop ransomware loaders.

143.description: Clear-text email retrieval—the harvested creds often unlock VPN or Windows domain accounts used by OT staff.

161.description:
“public/private” communities expose switch configs, VLAN IDs, and process P&IDs. Write access flips
network-gear ACLs in seconds.

162.description: Spoofed traps suppress real alarms or trigger disruptive fail-open states in safety logic.

1701.description: Frequently deployed without IPsec. Gives adversaries an easy intra-plant tunnel if pre-shared keys leak.

389.description:
Active Directory queries in clear-text expose usernames, group membership, and password-policy info.
LDAP-signing & channel binding are rarely enabled in mixed-vendor OT domains.

443.description:
Safe only with valid certs, strict-TLS, and HSTS. Self-signed or expired‐cert devices downgrade to
SSL 3.0 / TLS 1.0—easy prey for downgrade or BEAST attacks.

445.description:
EternalBlue, NotPetya, Ryuk, and countless worm families pivot here. Disable SMBv1, require SMB signing,
and isolate engineering shares.

464.description:
Password-change channel; malicious password-spray generates noisy kpasswd traffic—good IOC for brute
forcing.

500.description:
Weak pre-shared keys or aggressive-mode IKE v1 leak hash material; compromises site-to-site tunnels that
bridge OT to corp IT.

502.description:
No auth/encryption. Write-single-coil can start pumps, open breakers, or crash RTUs. Monitor for function
codes 5,6,15,16 from unexpected IPs.

514.description:
Plain-text logs can be spoofed or suppressed; attackers erase forensic evidence by flooding with fake
“normal-operation” messages.

515.description: Printer firmware in OT corridors is rarely patched; buffer-overflow exploits grant foothold behind firewalls.

587.description: STARTTLS downgrades or invalid certs revert to clear-text. Enforce TLS 1.2+ and DANE/DMARC for integrity.

593.description:
Often overlooked in firewall rules; NTLM relaying here skips SMB signing defenses, aiding hash relay from
corp IT into the plant.

623.description:
Default “ADMIN/ADMIN” creds grant KVM, power-cycle, and virtual media insert. In OT, an attacker can shut
down safety PLCs through remote BMCs.

631.description: Printer job uploads can smuggle data out or deploy malicious firmware updates into trusted OT zones.

636.description:
Secure binding fails if OT devices trust any cert—man-in-the-middle with rogue LDAPs proxies harvest or
inject group membership.

873.description:
Plain-text deltas transmit sensitive PLC source. Weak module auth enables overwrite of startup scripts on
engineering HMI hosts.

902.description: Attackers copy full HMI VMDKs or inject rogue snapshots that auto-start C2 implants when the VM boots.

912.description: Often left open to entire plant LAN; any hijack yields keyboard/mouse to SCADA VMs.

989-990.description: Misconfigured implicit vs explicit TLS causes downgrade; legacy engineering tools revert to clear-text FTP.

1025-1028.description:
Dynamic RPC endpoints that slide through poorly written ACLs; many ICS malware families (Industroyer,
LockerGoga) keep beacons here.

1433.description:
OT historians often run as ‘sa’. SQL injection or credential reuse exposes years of batch records and
recipe logs.

1434.description: UDP pings return instance names, ports, and versions—ideal for automated exploit kits.

1521.description:
Oracle DBs underpin MES/ERP links; SID brute-force plus default ‘SCOTT/TIGER’ still lands shells in older
plants.

2049.description:
UID/GID spoofing mounts controller backups, batch files, or recipe libraries. OT often lacks Kerberos/AES
for secure NFSv4.

2375.description:
Exposes root-level container control; ‘docker run --privileged’ gives instant host escape. Seen on edge
gateways where devs enabled remote build.

2376.description: Security collapses if the TLS CA is public or if daemon runs with `--tlsverify` disabled.

2483-2484.description: 2483 = clear-text; 2484 = TLS. Mismatched configuration silently falls back to insecure 2483.

2525.description: Cloud relays default here when 25/587 blocked. Apply same SPF/DKIM/MTA-STS controls to prevent spoofing.

27017.description:
Default “bindIp 0.0.0.0” + no auth: ransomware wipes historian data, then sells copies of production
metrics.

27018-27019.description: Sharded clusters often exposed internally with no TLS; compromise lets attackers rewrite process data.

3000.description: By default no TLS and admin:admin. Compromise provides query access to OPC UA back-ends and process KPIs.

3306.description: Hard-coded creds in SCADA apps still common. SQL map and MySQL-dump exfil entire historian schemas.

3389.description:
Brute-force, BlueKeep (CVE-2019-0708), clipboard exfil, and drive-redirection all threaten integrity of
Level-1 & Level-2 assets.

4011.description: Rogue PXE server pushes attacker-controlled boot images to HMI thin clients during power-up.

4022.description: Message queues carry batch instructions; intercepted traffic allows injection of bogus work orders.

4444.description:
Unexpected listeners here are textbook post-exploitation. Block outbound 4444/4443 and monitor for new
LISTEN sockets.

5000.description:
Engineers prototype quick dashboards but forget to add auth; attackers trigger flow uploads that run
shell commands on the OT gateway.

5022.description:
Clear-text mirrors reveal live financial/production data; unauthorized mirrors siphon continuous replicas
off-site.

5432.description:
Default ‘postgres’ superuser and password reuse plague open-source MES adapters; COPY TO PROGRAM lets
attackers execute OS commands.

5555.description:
Smart-HMI tablets ship with ADB over TCP enabled; attackers install rogue APKs or capture screen video of
operator panels.

5672.description:
Clear-text message bus feeds order IDs and set-points to PLC gateways; hijack injects falsified production
commands.

5900.description:
Weak DES password hash, no channel encryption. Grants full mouse/keyboard to safety PLC consoles if left
open.

5938.description:
Cloud broker circumvents inbound firewall checks; stolen creds + “Easy Access” expose HMIs to the internet.
Enforce MFA and on-demand enablement only.

6000.description:
Legacy UNIX HMIs still export X sessions; keystrokes and screen data flow in clear-text—an attacker can fully
remote-control the display manager.

6379.description:
No auth by default. Writing an SSH key to `/root/.ssh/authorized_keys` via Redis “CONFIG SET dir …” gives
root shell on many edge gateways.

6667.description: Outbound IRC from operators’ workstations is a red-flag; modern malware still uses IRC for botnet C2.

7070.description:
AnyDesk tunnels outbound on 80/443 if 7070 blocked. Whitelist trusted IDs and force session recording; rogue
AnyDesk installs give silent desktop control.

8080.description:
Proxy & Tomcat consoles often forgotten in security scans. Attackers slip PHP web-shells or proxy C2 over
whitelisted 8080.

8081.description:
Jenkins, Nexus, and other CI servers default here—prime targets for supply-chain implant of PLC firmware
toolchains.

8443.description:
Self-signed certs and deprecated ciphers still rampant; MITM strips TLS then injects malicious Java applets
into legacy engineering suites.

9000-9001.description:
OPC UA Discovery on 4840 by default, but 9000/9001 appear in bespoke builds; unauthenticated browse exposes
tag lists and node attributes useful for attack planning.

9200-9300.description:
OT log aggregators often leave ES open with no auth. Querying `/_cat/indices` leaks operator passwords in
clear-text logs; cluster port 9300 enables remote-code via deserialization exploits.

12345.description:
“nc -l -p 12345 -e /bin/sh” is still copy-pasted by red-teamers. Block and monitor for outbound 12345/udp
payloads in DPI engines.

49152-65535.description:
DCOM/SMB dynamic-ports bypass static ACLs if “Allow all high ports” is configured. Segment and firewall
these ranges to stop lateral movement.

null.service: Generic Multicast / Broadcast (mDNS, SSDP, EIGRP, IGMP floods)
null.description:
Excess multicast saturates deterministic control loops and hides discovery scans. Filter 224.0.0.0/4,
disable unused L2 protocols (CDP, LLDP), and rate-limit IGMP.
